cards.name: Tome of Infinity
cards.originalText: You may choose any number of additional modes on spells and abilities you control. You can't choose the same mode more than once this way. (Modes are generally indicated after "Choose one.")

rulings.text: You can use this to get around paying entwine costs, but not escalate costs.
This does not work with Citadel Siege or similar cards, because the anchor words “Khans” and “Dragons” are not modes.

When using this ability, you cannot choose the same mode more than once even if the modal spell normally allows you to do so. For example, if you cast Consulate Emergency while you control Tome of Infinity, you can still only choose two modes.

cards.name: Mount Chromaziel
cards.originalText:
{T}, Reveal a land card from your hand: Add to your mana pool one mana of any type that the revealed card could produce.
{W}{U}{B}{R}{G}, {T}: Search your library for a multicolored card, reveal it, and put it into your hand. Then shuffle your library.

rulings.text: The types of mana are {W}, {U}, {B}, {R}, {G}, and {C}.

To determine what types of mana the revealed card could produce, look at all activated and triggered abilities of that card, including non-mana abilities, and determine which types of mana they could produce if they were to resolve right now, taking into account any replacement effects, but ignoring the abilities' costs.
If the revealed card couldn't produce mana, Mount Chromaziel does not produce any mana. It won't produce colorless mana instead.
If you reveal another Mount Chromaziel, no mana is produced. Your hand is a hidden zone, even if some or all cards in it happen to be revealed.
If you reveal Crumbling Vestige, Mount Chromaziel can produce any type of mana. The mana that could be produced doesn't have to come from a mana ability.
If you reveal Desert Temple or Dream Frontier, Mount Chromaziel can produce any type of mana, regardless of whether you control any creatures.
If you reveal Dreamborn Paradise, no mana is produced. No color has been chosen.
If you reveal Frontier Outpost, Moxenite Mine, Unknown Shores, or Valley of Pyramids, Mount Chromaziel can produce any type of mana.
If you reveal Madame Tawney's Saloon, Mount Chromaziel can produce colored mana only if you control a nonland permanent. It can always produce {C}.
If you reveal Mana Confluence, Mount Chromaziel can produce any color of mana, but not {C}.
If you reveal Memory Lane, Mount Chromaziel produces {C}. The Memory Lane in your hand doesn't have a voyage counter on it.

rulings.text: A permanent is “tapped for {G}” when an activated mana ability of that permanent whose cost includes {T} produces at least {G}.
An activated ability is a mana ability if it could add mana, doesn't target, and isn't a loyalty ability.
The intrinsic mana ability of a Forest meets these criteria.

cards.name: Daumas Patrol
cards.originalText:
Create two 2/2 white Knight creature tokens with vigilance.
Premonition 4—{1}{W} (Rather than cast this card from your hand, you may pay {1}{W} and put this card into your library face up just beneath the top four cards. As it reaches the top, cast it without paying its mana cost.)

rulings.text: If a library contains multiple consecutive face-up cards and they reach the top, first simultaneously put them onto the stack in the same order they were in the library, then finish casting them (announce targets, etc) from bottom to top. The card that was topmost in the library will resolve first.
Revealing, looking at, searching, shuffling, or otherwise reordering face-up cards in a library turns them face down.

Casting a card with premonition interrupts whatever you're doing. For example, if the 3rd card in your library is face up and you resolve Preordain (“Scry 2, then draw a card.”), moving both cards to the bottom of your library, then you will first cast the face-up card and then draw the card that was originally 4th from the top.

When you look at or reveal cards in a library, those cards are still in that library. For example, if the 2nd card in your library is face up and you scry 1, you only cast the face-up card if you put the card you're scrying on the bottom.

rulings.text: If a library contains multiple consecutive face-up cards and they reach the top, first simultaneously put them onto the stack in the same order they were in the library, then finish casting them (announce targets, etc) from bottom to top. The card that was topmost in the library will resolve first.
Revealing, looking at, searching, shuffling, or otherwise reordering face-up cards in a library turns them face down.

Casting a card with premonition interrupts whatever you're doing. For example, if the 3rd card in your library is face up and you resolve Preordain (“Scry 2, then draw a card.”), moving both cards to the bottom of your library, then you will first cast the face-up card and then draw the card that was originally 4th from the top.

When you look at or reveal cards in a library, those cards are still in that library. For example, if the 2nd card in your library is face up and you scry 1, you only cast the face-up card if you put the card you're scrying on the bottom.

cards.name: Foredoom
cards.originalText:
Destroy all creatures and planeswalkers.
Premonition 7—{B} (Rather than cast this card from your hand, you may pay {B} and put this card into your library face up just beneath the top seven cards. As it reaches the top, cast it without paying its mana cost.)

rulings.text: If a library contains multiple consecutive face-up cards and they reach the top, first simultaneously put them onto the stack in the same order they were in the library, then finish casting them (announce targets, etc) from bottom to top. The card that was topmost in the library will resolve first.
Revealing, looking at, searching, shuffling, or otherwise reordering face-up cards in a library turns them face down.

Casting a card with premonition interrupts whatever you're doing. For example, if the 3rd card in your library is face up and you resolve Preordain (“Scry 2, then draw a card.”), moving both cards to the bottom of your library, then you will first cast the face-up card and then draw the card that was originally 4th from the top.

When you look at or reveal cards in a library, those cards are still in that library. For example, if the 2nd card in your library is face up and you scry 1, you only cast the face-up card if you put the card you're scrying on the bottom.

rulings.text: If a library contains multiple consecutive face-up cards and they reach the top, first simultaneously put them onto the stack in the same order they were in the library, then finish casting them (announce targets, etc) from bottom to top. The card that was topmost in the library will resolve first.
Revealing, looking at, searching, shuffling, or otherwise reordering face-up cards in a library turns them face down.

Casting a card with premonition interrupts whatever you're doing. For example, if the 3rd card in your library is face up and you resolve Preordain (“Scry 2, then draw a card.”), moving both cards to the bottom of your library, then you will first cast the face-up card and then draw the card that was originally 4th from the top.

When you look at or reveal cards in a library, those cards are still in that library. For example, if the 2nd card in your library is face up and you scry 1, you only cast the face-up card if you put the card you're scrying on the bottom.

cards.name: Aisha's Caretaker
cards.originalText:
{1}: Put the top card of your library into your graveyard.
{3}{G}{U}, {T}: Put a nonland card from your graveyard into your library face up just beneath the top three cards of that library. That card gains premonition. (As a face-up card with premonition is on top of your library, cast it without paying its mana cost.)

rulings.text: If a library contains multiple consecutive face-up cards and they reach the top, first simultaneously put them onto the stack in the same order they were in the library, then finish casting them (announce targets, etc) from bottom to top. The card that was topmost in the library will resolve first.
Revealing, looking at, searching, shuffling, or otherwise reordering face-up cards in a library turns them face down.

Casting a card with premonition interrupts whatever you're doing. For example, if the 3rd card in your library is face up and you resolve Preordain (“Scry 2, then draw a card.”), moving both cards to the bottom of your library, then you will first cast the face-up card and then draw the card that was originally 4th from the top.

When you look at or reveal cards in a library, those cards are still in that library. For example, if the 2nd card in your library is face up and you scry 1, you only cast the face-up card if you put the card you're scrying on the bottom.

cards.name: Ciaran, Blade of the Lords
cards.originalText:
Deathtouch
When Ciaran, Blade of the Lords enters the battlefield, each opponent chooses a creature card name.
Ciaran can't be blocked except by creatures with one of the chosen names.

rulings.text: Only names of actual creature cards can be used. For example, Wandering Fumarole cannot be named even if a Wandering Fumarole on the battlefield is currently a creature. Similarly, most tokens cannot be named, with the exception of tokens with names that are also creature card names. At the time of this ruling, the only such tokens other than token copies are Assembly-Worker, Cloud Sprite, Festering Goblin, Goldmeadow Harrier, Kobolds of Kher Keep, Llanowar Elves, Metallic Sliver, Nightmare, Shapeshifter, and Spark Elemental.

cards.name: Deflect
cards.originalText: Prevent the next X damage that would be dealt to you and/or permanents you control this turn. If damage is prevented this way, Deflect deals that much damage to each opponent.

rulings.text: Deflect can prevent damage that would be dealt to you, one or more creatures you control, and/or one or more planeswalkers you control.

Deflect can prevent damage from multiple sources dealing damage simultaneously (such as during combat). If the chosen value for X won't prevent all the damage, you choose which sources to prevent damage from.

If damage is dealt to multiple permanents you control, or is dealt to you and at least one permanent you control, you choose which of that damage to prevent if the chosen value for X won't prevent all the damage. For example, if 3 damage would be dealt to you and to each of two creatures you control, and Deflect will prevent the next 3 damage, you might choose to prevent the next 2 damage it would deal to you and the next 1 damage it would deal to one of the creatures, among other choices. You don't decide until the point at which the damage would be dealt.

Deflect's effect is not a redirection effect. If it prevents damage, Deflect (not the original source) deals damage to each opponent as part of that prevention effect. Deflect is the source of the new damage, so the characteristics of the original source (such as its color, or whether it had lifelink or deathtouch) don't affect this damage. The new damage is not combat damage, even if the prevented damage was. Since you control the source of the new damage, for each opponent who controls one or more planeswalkers, you may have Deflect deal damage to one of those planeswalkers instead of that opponent.

If Deflect prevents damage, excess damage (if any) dealt by that source is dealt at the same time. Immediately afterward, as part of that same prevention effect, Deflect deals its damage. This happens before state-based actions are checked, and before the spell or ability that caused damage to be dealt resumes its resolution.

cards.name: Snake Oil Salesman
cards.originalText:
{T}: Create a colorless artifact token named Snake Oil.
{3}{U}{U}, {T}: Exchange control of two target nonland permanents for as long as you control Snake Oil Salesman.

rulings.text: Control is only exchanged if both targets are still legal as the ability resolves.
If you exchange the Salesman for something, that exchange will remain active as long as you would control the Salesman if not for the exchange. Any other exchanges will end immediately.

If Snake Oil Salesman leaves the battlefield or leaves your control through some other effect, the control-changing effects immediately end and control of the permanents returns to the previous player. If one of the permanents no longer exists, the other is still returned.
If any creatures are involved in the exchange, they will become summoning sick both when the effect begins and when it ends.
The Snake Oil token doesn't do anything.

cards.name: Pactbound Simians
cards.originalText:
Flying
At the beginning of your upkeep, choose one that hasn't been chosen —
• Target opponent sacrifices a creature.
• Target opponent discards a card.
• Target opponent sacrifices a land.
• Sacrifice Pactbound Simians.

rulings.text: You choose the mode as the triggered ability goes on the stack. You can choose a mode that requires targets only if there are legal targets available.
If the ability is countered (either for having its target become illegal or because a spell or ability counters it), the mode chosen for that instance of the ability still counts as being chosen.

The phrase "that hasn't been chosen" refers only to that specific Pactbound Simians. If you control one and cast another one, you can choose any mode for the second one the first time its ability triggers.

It doesn't matter who has chosen any particular mode. For example, say you control Pactbound Simians and have chosen the first two modes. If an opponent gains control of Pactbound Simians, that player can choose only the third or fourth mode.

In some very unusual situations, you may not be able to choose a mode, either because all modes have previously been chosen or the only remaining modes require targets and there are no legal targets available. In this case, the ability is simply removed from the stack with no effect.
Yes, if the fourth mode is the only one remaining, you must choose it. You read the whole contract, right?

rulings.text: If you control a straight of 6 or more, you also control a straight of 5, consisting of 5 cmc-adjacent cards in the longer straight.

For example, if you have green permanents with cmc 1-2-3-4-5 and a 6-cost blue permanent, the effect will work. Same if your 6-cost permanent is also green. If you have blue permanents with cmc 1-2-3 and 5-6 but your only 4-drop is white, it won't work.

cards.originalText: Until end of turn, target creature gets +6/+6 and gains trample, and all creatures able to block it this turn do so.

rulings.text: If, during the declare blockers step, a creature the defending player controls is tapped (or untapped, if the targeted creature has dreamwalk) or is affected by a spell or ability that says it can't block, then it doesn't block. If there's a cost associated with having it block, its controller isn't forced to pay that cost. If he or she doesn't, the creature doesn't have to block.

If a creature can't legally block the targeted creature but could block another attacking creature, it may do so. Likewise, if a creature the defending player controls can't block the targeted creature unless its controller pays a cost, its controller may decline to pay that cost and block a different attacking creature.

cards.name: Colossus of Railroads
cards.originalText:
Colossus of Railroads' power and toughness are each equal to the number of artifacts you control.
When Colossus of Railroads dies, you may distribute a number of +1/+1 counters equal to its power among any number of creatures you control.

rulings.text: The ability that triggers when Colossus of Railroads dies doesn't target any of the creatures. You can choose to put counters on a creature with protection from artifacts, for example.
You choose how the counters will be distributed when the ability resolves.

If the Colossus dies to an effect that reduced its toughness to 0 or less, that effect will be considered when determining how many counters are distributed. If it also reduced its power to 0 or less, no counters are distributed.

{T}: Add {R}. When that mana is spent to cast an instant or sorcery spell, exile it when it resolves.
{4}, {T}, Sacrifice Roselyn's Viola: Cast any number of cards exiled with Roselyn's Viola without paying their mana costs. (They are put into their owner's graveyards.)

rulings.text: The exile effect can only find the instant or sorcery card if it's in a graveyard because it finished resolving. A spell that removes itself from the stack during resolution, such as Tall Tales, cannot be exiled with the Viola.
If Viola mana is spent to cast a spell for its flashback cost, the exile effect from flashback applies first. You will not be able to cast it with the Viola.
You still pay any additional costs when casting spells with the second ability.

rulings.text: The first ability works if your current life total is below or above your starting life total. For example, if your starting life total was 20, the Titan will enter with 3 counters if you're at 17 life, but also if you're at 23 life.

For your life total to become your starting life total (normally 20), you gain the appropriate amount of life. For example, if your life total is 17 when the trigger resolves, it will cause you to gain 3 life. Other cards that interact with life gain will interact with this effect accordingly.

rulings.text: Note that the ability merely counteracts the effect of the counters. A Henchfiend with 3 -1/-1 counters on it is still a 3/2, not a 6/5.

+1/+1 counters and -1/-1 counters annihilate each other each time state-based actions are checked. If you have a Henchfiend with a -1/-1 counter on it and a spell puts a +1/+1 counter on it, Henchfiend will be a 4/3 until the spell finishes resolving, at which point SBAs are checked and it will be a 3/2 again.
